intro: Hydnophytum kelelense, commonly known as the Kellelense mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees in tropical rainforests. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while also obtaining some photosynthetic capability through its own leaves. The plant produces small, white flowers that are often clustered together, and its fruit is a capsule that releases tiny seeds. Hydnophytum kelelense is typically found in the understory of dense, humid forests, where it thrives in shaded environments. Due to its specialized growth habits, it plays a unique role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat.
